oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Correspondence

Patterson, Malcolm R. (Malcolm Rice), 1861-1935; Alexander, Truman Hudson, 1891-1941; Bryan, William Jennings, 1860-1925; Evolution; Creationism; Evolution (Biology) - Study and teaching - Law and legislation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter, written shortly after the end of the Scopes Trial, sent to former governor Malcolm R. Patterson by Nashville Tennessean managing editor and Governor Austin Peay advisor, Truman Alexander. Alexander sought to inform Patterson of William Jennings; Bryan's regard for him and his desire to have Patterson as a member of the prosecution team at the John T. Scopes Trial.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Alexander, Truman Hudson, 1891-1941
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: As an advisor to Governor Austin Peay, Truman Alexander had access to the Governor's papers and had come across a letter to Peay from William Jennings Brayn, dated June 27, 1925, furnishing the comments concerning Patterson. Governor Austin Peay held the; office of Tennessee governor from 1923 to 1927; he had signed the Butler Bill in 1925, whose passage had set in motion the events leading up to the Scopes Trial in Dayton, Tennessee, in July of 1925.
